docs.title: Administrator web interface
docs.description: YunoHost has an administrator web interface. The other way to administrate your YunoHost install is through the command line.

docs.title: Applications
docs.description: One of the key feature of YunoHost is the ability to easily install applications which are then immediately usable. Example of applications include a blog system, a "cloud" (to host and sync files), a website, an RSS reader...

docs.title: Installing "custom" apps
docs.description: While YunoHost has many apps available in the catalog, you may want to install apps that are not available in the official catalog, or setup your very own website that you crafted using HTML / CSS / PHP ..

docs.title: SSH and command line
docs.description: What's SSH?

docs.title: Certificate
docs.description: Certificates are used to guarantee the confidentiality and authenticity of the communication between a web browser and your server. In particular, they protect against attackers trying to impersonate your server.

docs.title: Domains
docs.description: YunoHost lets you manage and serve multiple domains on a single server. So you can host, for example, a blog and Nextcloud on a first domain yolo.com, and a webmail client on a second domain swag.nohost.me. Each domain is automatically configured to handle web services and e-mail.

docs.title: Emails
docs.description: YunoHost comes with a complete mail stack allowing you to host your own email server, and therefore to have your own email addresses in something@your.domain.tld.

docs.title: Advices and guidelines
docs.description: This page lists some advice and guidelines which every YunoHost administrator should be aware to take care of a YunoHost server :)

docs.title: Guided tour for the admin
docs.description: This page provide an overview of the ecosystem of a YunoHost server. While this overview contains several approximations, the purpose here is to introduce the global picture before digging into the different aspects.

docs.title: Migrating from 11.x to 12.x
docs.description: This page is dedicated to help you migrating an instance from YunoHost 11.x (running on Debian Bullseye) to YunoHost 12 (running on Debian Bookworm).

docs.title: Migration isues FAQ
docs.description: This page lists all the known issues encountered after a migration from YunoHost 11 to 12.

docs.title: Migrating from 4.x to 11.x
docs.description: This page is dedicated to help you migrating an instance from YunoHost 4.4.x (running on Debian Buster/10.x) to YunoHost 11.x (running on Debian Bullseye/11.x). Note: we decided to skip the version numbers from 5 to 10 to follow the Debian version numbers.

docs.title: Upgrades
docs.description: From the webadmin

docs.title: Users groups and permissions
docs.description: You can access the groups and permissions management interface from the webadmin

docs.title: Users and the SSO
docs.description: Users

docs.title: Avoid hardware failure
docs.description: Physically secure your server

docs.title: Backup methods
docs.description: YunoHost currently has three apps integrating backup solutions offering more features than the simple ".tar" mechanism shipped in YunoHost, in particular automatic and remote backups.

docs.title: Snapshotting the entire filesystem
docs.description: YunoHost's backup tool only backs up useful files and relies on restore scripts to reinstall the dependencies of your applications. In other words, YunoHost's mechanism amounts to reinstalling and then reincorporating the data.

docs.title: Custom backup methods
docs.description: It is possible to create your own backup method and link it to YunoHost's backup file collection system. This can be useful if you want to use your own backup software or conduct disk mount/dismount operations for example.

docs.title: Backup strategies
docs.description: In the context of self-hosting, backups are an important element to compensate for unexpected events (fire, database corruption, loss of access to the server, compromised server...). The backup policy to implement depends on the importance of the services and data you manage. For example, backing up a test server will be of little interest, while you will want to be very careful if you are managing critical data for an association or a company - and in such cases, you will want to store the backups in a different location or locations.

docs.title: Include or exclude files
docs.description: Include files

docs.title: Backing up your server
docs.description: In the context of self-hosting, backups are an important element to compensate for unexpected events (fire, database corruption, loss of access to the server, compromised server...). The backup policy to implement depends on the importance of the services and data you manage. For example, backing up a test server will be of little interest, while you will want to be very careful if you are managing critical data for an association or a company - and in such cases, you will want to store the backups in a different location or locations.

docs.title: Migrate or merge servers
docs.description: Migrate a server

docs.title: Unblacklisting forms
docs.description: It could happen sometimes that your IP is blacklisted by some email provider, or anti-spam services. If you receive an alert from the diagnosis tool, click on details to find the unblocking forms.

docs.title: Changing the administration password
docs.description: You may want to change your administrator password for security reason or because you forgot it.

docs.title: Cleanup
docs.description: These are a few guidelines on how to perform some cleanup on the server, for instance when storage space becomes a bit short.

docs.title: IP address unban
docs.description: Fail2Ban is an intrusion prevention software that protects computer servers against brute-force attacks. It monitors certain logs and will ban IP addresses that show brute-force-like behavior.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.description: This section contains specific tips to troubleshoot common issues.

docs.title: Setting up IPv6
docs.description: IPv6 may work out of the box in many cases. But in some cases or some specific provider, you may need to tweak things manually to enable IPv6.

docs.title: Get access back into YunoHost
docs.description: There are several reasons that could lead to one administrator's access being partially or completely blocked off their YunoHost server. In numerous cases, one of the access methods is blocked, but others are not.

docs.title: Custom certificates
docs.description: Since version 2.5, YunoHost integrates Let's Encrypt certificates automated management. You can easily and freely install a Let's Encrypt certificate. The following document describes the steps for installing a paid certificate from a certification authority (Gandi, RapidSSL, StartSSL, Cacert).

docs.title: DNS with a dynamic IP
docs.description: Before going further, make sure your global IP address is dynamic with: ip.yunohost.org. The global IP address of your box changes almost every day.

next.title: Local network access to your server

docs.title: Local network access to your server
docs.description: After completing your server installation, it is possible that your domain will not be accessible through the local network. This is an issue known as hairpinning - a feature that is not well supported by some internet routers.

frontMatter.title: Local network access to your server

docs.title: Nohost.me domains
docs.description: In order to make self-hosting as accessible as possible, the YunoHost Project provides a free and automatically configured domain name service. By using this service, you won't have to configure DNS records yourself, which can be tedious and technical.

previous.title: Local network access to your server

docs.title: Configure SMTP relay
docs.description: If your ISP blocks port 25, if you can't set a reverseDNS on your server, or if you have any other troubles using the built-in SMTP server on YunoHost, you may want to setup your YunoHost server to use an SMTP relay.

docs.title: Adding an external storage to your server
docs.description: Introduction

frontMatter.title: Adding an external storage to your server

docs.title: Exchange files with your server using a graphical interface
docs.description: This page explains how to exchange files (backup archives, music, pictures, movies...) with your server using a graphical interface for the (S)FTP protocol. This is an alternative to using scp which can be deemed technical and cryptic, or using an app like Nextcloud.

frontMatter.title: Exchange files with your server using a graphical interface

docs.title: Moving an app folder to a different storage
docs.description: Applications folder are (usually) located in /var/www/$appname

frontMatter.title: Moving an app folder to a different storage

docs.title: Security
docs.description: YunoHost has been developed to provide the best security without too much complication. Every protocol used in YunoHost is encrypted, only a password's hashes are stored and by default each user is able to access their personal directory only.

docs.title: Give SFTP permission to edit an app
docs.description: In YunoHost permission management web admin interface, you can specify which user can access your system through SFTP.

frontMatter.title: Give SFTP permission to edit an app

docs.description: Even though YunoHost contributors try to continuously perfect it, YunoHost itself, its packages or this documentation are not free from bugs or flaw. To let us help you, however, you need to follow these guidelines.

docs.title: Advanced packagers
docs.description: Here comes the time:

docs.title: Config Panels
docs.description: From a practical point of view, one of the main purpose of config panel is to "expose" settings from the app's configuration files to YunoHost's admins which are therefore able to manipulate them from a nice web ui. This is especially relevant for apps which do not provide any sort of admin UI and expect admins to manually edit the configuration files.

docs.title: Hooks
docs.description: YunoHost includes a hook mechanism triggered on a lot of operation changing the system. You can use this mechanism in order to extend the behaviour of a YunoHost command.

docs.title: Packaging v2
docs.description: Packaging v2 is a major improvement for the packaging introduced in YunoHost 11.1

docs.title: SSO/LDAP integration
docs.description: One powerful aspect of YunoHost is that apps are meant to be integrated with the SSO/LDAP stack, such that users logged in on YunoHost's user portal can be directly logged in each app without having to create an account in each of them nor having to re-log in each app every time.

docs.title: Adding documentation to your app
docs.description: Properly documenting your app is important for user experience ;).

docs.title: Packaging applications
docs.description: This documentation is here to provide all the basic concepts and vocabulary needed to understand app packaging.

docs.title: App resources
docs.description: Doc auto-generated by this script on 14/03/2025 (YunoHost version 12.1.2)

docs.title: Writing the app manifest
docs.description: The app's manifest.toml can be seen as the ID card of the app. It declares various basic metadata such as the id, name, description of the app, its version, install questions to be asked to the admin prior to installation, etc.

docs.title: Writing app scripts
docs.description: App scripts are the essential logic defining what happens when an app is installed, removed, upgraded, backuped, or restored. They are written in Bash) which is the same stuff you type in interactive mode in a terminal, though we added a bunch of custom YunoHost functions that we call helpers to standardize many common operations - for example adding the nginx configuration.

docs.description: Variables exists for the current shell and its children only.

docs.title: Testing your app
docs.description: Once you're done writing you app package, you'll want to check that everything works correctly. At first, you can manually try to install your app on some test server of your own : sudo yunohost app install ./path/to/mycustomapp_ynh

docs.description: It is of course possible to contribute directly to the YunoHost documentation, but this is not the most convenient way to do so for both the contributor and the person who will inject your contribution into the documentation. Here is a tutorial to understand and create a contribution to the YunoHost documentation using Git and GitHub.com which is the Git forge service that hosts and stores the YunoHost source code and documentation.

docs.title: Markdown Guide
docs.description: Markdown is a markup language created in 2004, many add-ons developing the possibilities of this language exist. The objective of this guide is to aim for the exhaustiveness of the possibilities of this formatting language within the framework of the YunoHost documentation and not Markdown languages in general.

docs.title: Docs introduction
docs.description: This is the documentation for YunoHost, a libre operating system aiming to simplify server administration and democratize self-hosting.

docs.title: Choose your selfhosting method and providers
docs.description: You can host yourself at home (on a small computer), or on a remote server. Each solution has their pros and cons:

docs.description: Since version 4.3, YunoHost includes a mechanism to interface your server with your DNS registrar API, with the purpose of simplifying and automatizing DNS records registration and maintenance.

docs.title: Advantage of a VPN for self-hosting
docs.description: Since setting up a server at home is an uncommon practice, most Internet connections provided to individuals are unsuitable for this purpose. A net neutral VPN providing a static IPv4 address and IPv6 addresses can help to circumvent some limitations or difficulties.
